thread.title: Browns will 'strongly consider' trading for Jimmy Garoppolo, report says
thread.title_full: Browns will 'strongly consider' trading for Jimmy Garoppolo, report says

author: Brandon Schlager (bschlager@sportingnews.com)
title: Browns will 'strongly consider' trading for Jimmy Garoppolo, report says
text:
NFL February 1, 2017 12:19am EST February 1, 2017 12:19am EST American Football, News, English, Jimmy Garoppolo, NFL, Cleveland Browns, New England Patriots Cleveland's search for a 27th starting quarterback since 1999 could well settle on the Patriots' backup, at a cost. Jimmy Garoppolo (Getty Images) 
Updated at 12:19 a.m. ET 
Updated at 12:19 a.m. ET 
The Browns, users of 26 starting quarterbacks since 1999, have options in their search to find No. 27. 
Cleveland could use its No. 1 or No. 12 overall pick to draft one in April, or they might instead decide to pay a premium to acquire Tom Brady understudy Jimmy Garoppolo from the Patriots, a move that likely would require one of the aforementioned picks plus more going back to New England. 
The Browns at least will "strongly consider" Option No. 2, Mary Kay Cabot of Cleveland.com reported Tuesday . 
“Sources say the Browns’ interest in Garoppolo is real and that they’ll try to trade for him depending on how their draft evaluations go over the next five weeks or so,” Cabot wrote. 
Those five weeks will be spent pouring over tape of UNC's Mitch Trubisky or Clemson's Deshaun Watson, the consensus top two quarterbacks in this year's draft class, as well as other potential options the Browns could snag further down the board with one of their 13 picks. 
None will be as prepared to start in 2017 as Garoppolo, who has shown flashes during his three NFL seasons. But he remains a risky gamble. 
The 25-year-old has made two starts, both in 2016, when he threw for a combined 496 yards and four touchdowns as the Patriots started 2-0 with Brady suspended. Garoppolo showed poise and talent that made him a second-round pick in 2014, but that's his resume in a nutshell. 
Critics will say he's another product of the Bill Belichick system. 
After all, the Patriots have pulled this trick before, cashing in on Matt Cassel (in 2009) and Ryan Mallett (in 2014). Neither panned out with their new teams. 
Garoppolo figures to draw at least a first-round pick from suitors as the Patriots hope for a bidding war between the many quarterback-needy teams. 
It's likely there will be plenty of them besides the Browns, including the 49ers, as Cabot notes. But the Browns seem willing to pay the price. Watch This
